title.narrative: Provision of winterization assistance to vulnerable households in Ferozkoh district of Ghor province

description.narrative:
According to the Joint Winterization Strategy (dated July 2020), 799,000 people in Ghor will be exposed to harsh winter weather in the coming winter season. Local communities already experience the devastating effects of the Covid-19 pandemic, which has led to widespread illness and mortality, a deep economic recession, and starkly reduced income opportunities. The pandemic has depleted productive assets and reduced communities’ capacity to cope with shocks. This situation is expected to continue through 2020, as vulnerable households are exposed to further shocks including loss of employment, reduced income, and rising prices over the lean season. Afghanaid’s needs assessment (attached as Annex A), conducted in September 2020 in Ferozkoh district of Ghor, found that the vast majority of households in the district are unable to cover their basic needs and resort to negative coping strategies. In response to this crisis, Afghanaid proposes to provide 300 IDP households in Ferozkoh with lifesaving shelter assistance and a total of 1,300 households with critical heating assistance. Based on a unanimous community preference for cash transfers and a recent market assessment (attached as Annex B) confirming community access to well-functioning markets, Afghanaid proposes cash as the assistance modality.
In line with Emergency Shelter and Non-Food Items Cluster priorities as detailed in the Joint Winterization Strategy, Afghanaid proposes to provide 300 vulnerable households in Ferozkoh district with a standard rent assistance package for three months, or US$225 per household. Those same households and 1000 additional households (500 IDP and 500 host community) will receive a standard heating assistance package for 4 months through a cash transfer of US$260 per household. A beneficiary selection and distribution committee will be established which will include representatives from local communities (e.g. CDC and DDA heads), Government departments (e.g. ANDMA and DoRR), IoM and Afghanaid staff. Beneficiaries will be selected according to ESNFI vulnerability criteria to ensure the most acutely in need and vulnerable are targeted, including displaced people, women-headed households and households with a large number of dependent children.
To carry out the cash distribution, contracts will be established with a reliable saraf. The cash will then be distributed at central distribution points in two tranches. Rent assistance recipients will be required to present a copy of their rental agreement, or will be supported to set up a rental contract where such a document is not yet in place. They will receive US$75 as a first tranche, and after submission of their rental invoice, the second tranche of US$150. Heating assistance recipients will receive their assistance in a US$20 first tranche to purchase a heater, and a US$240 second tranche for fuel which will require the recipient to show proof of purchase of the heater. Beneficiaries with limited mobility will be brought to the distribution point or will receive the assistance at their homes.
Afghanaid is well placed to implement this project, with 19 years of continuous presence in Ghor, current operations in the target district and excellent access and strong relationships with communities as well as district and provincial authorities. Afghanaid has extensive experience in humanitarian programming, with current and recent humanitarian assistance projects in multiple provinces including Ghor, funded by AHF, WFP, FAO, and ECHO. The projects include emergency food, livelihoods, winterization, and shelter assistance, using both in-kind and cash modalities.
This intervention will provide 9,100 vulnerable men, women, boys and girls with lifesaving shelter and heating, reducing illness and mortality as a result of exposure to the cold and increasing the beneficiaries’ capacity to build up their households’ financial buffers so that they are more resilient against future shocks.

title.narrative: Winterization Preparedness for most vulnerable communities in Badakhshan

description.narrative:
Aga Khan Agency for Habitat (AKAH)- an agency of the Aga Khan Development Network (AKDN) is one of the leading humanitarian and development agencies working in Afghanistan, Tajikistan, Syria, Pakistan and India. In Afghanistan it is operational in north eastern provinces of Afghanistan. AKAH is working in close coordination with eight line ministries and government agencies, especially Afghanistan National Disaster Management Authority (ANDMA), Provincial Disaster Management Committee (PDMC) and different UN clusters. AKAH is actively engaged with ES/NFIs Cluster at National and Provincial level.
AKAH had submitted the concept note for supporting the most vulnerable communities with winterization support in Badakhshan. These are most hard-hit provinces in terms of harsh winter. AKAH has a comprehensive hazard and vulnerability methodology (HVRA) used for assessments of various natural risks to communities residing in its target areas. Cumulatively, to date a total of 740 villages are covered through such assessments. Moreover, AKAH does a comprehensive winter preparedness planning, where the most vulnerable locations are considered for targeting.. Specifically, AKAH looks into set of critical indicators looking into proximity and access, exposure to hazards (avalanches, road blockage, etc.) and vulnerability of households (female headed households, widows, etc.).
As per the assessment the proposed targeted districts indicate that remoteness and inaccessibility and unavailability of resources makes community more vulnerable to the disaster risk. The situation got exacerbated due to COVID 19 pandemic.
Overall, it has been identified that a total of 448 most vulnerable families (3,136 people in total) are going to be covered through this winterization project. The intervention oversees the provision of standard ESNFI winterization items, specifically, 1) standard winter clothing package, 2) heating/fuel assistance, and 3) ESNFI blanket package. Due to shortage of items, AKAH will do a tender-based procurement of blanket package and standard winter clothing packages, considering the size and sex of beneficiaries at minimum, while the heating/fuel assistance will be provided through voucher modality, however, if no fuel items available in the local market or official vendors will do in cash through AWALA services, using standard tools for tracking cash distribution. The beneficiary selection and distribution will be undertaken in close cooperation with ANDMA, provincial level cluster partners at a regional level and district authorities, CDCs at the local level. The process will be thoroughly monitored and reported to respective stakeholders – PDMC, ANDMA, ESNFI cluster and local authorities. AKAH has partnership AWAAZ would be utilized as a feedback loop for the project. This will be done in addition to 24/7 call center of AKAH used for any communication and coordination with local stakeholders and the community. AKAH is very close the project location and is aware about the market situation. AKAH has already used such vendor based fuel support to its local offices. AKAH has good interaction with vendor and their capacities for the fuel distribution. AKAHA is well connected with them. Hence, it has only been proposed for Fuel support. Rest two components of Blanket and winter cloths would be provided through the kind support due to the availability of AKAH’s warehouses and connected with supplier, transporters and vendors for these items. It could be distributed within the communities in kind. Hence, AKAH has proposed the fuel support by Voucher modalities and Blanket and winter clothing by kind modalities. .

title.narrative: Supporting Vulnerable IDPs, Returnees, host community to meet their winterization needs through the Provision of Fuel and Heaters, Blankets package, and winter clothing kit in Paktika Province (Sharana, Zarghoon Shaher-Khair Kot and Jani Khel districts).

description.narrative:
The 2020 update to the 2018 - 2021 HRP seeks US$ 1.1 billion to reach 11.1 million people with emergency life-saving humanitarian and protection assistance across the country in 2020. The HRP’s strategic objectives, which are intended to span the entire life-cycle of the response, focus on the lives saved in the areas of highest needs. The 5th Reserved Allocation with a maximum total amount of US$ 15 million for life-saving humanitarian assistance in Afghanistan. The ES/ NFI cluster covers a total of 160,755 vulnerable individuals from the IDPs, returnees, and host communities with a total available fund of US$ 5 M to provide life-saving assistance for winterization through a winter response package of relief.
Vulnerability levels are expected to increase due to harsh winter conditions, with temperatures dropping as low as -12.1 degrees centigrade. A total of 1.3 million people will not have access to heating/fuel and other seasonal items needed to cope during the winter, people are in dire need of winterization package of (Fuel and heaters, Blankets package, and winter clothing kit) as they don’t have enough money to afford to purchase winterization packages to keep them warm. ORD will ensure that the most vulnerable people in need among the affected population group prioritized for the winterization response cash for fuel and heaters and in-kind blanket packages and winter clothing kit interventions to a single-family to holistically response their winterization needs. Moreover, the family doesn't qualify for all three packages it will receive only the needed package. ORD will use the specific vulnerability criteria for identifying the extremely vulnerable among the affected population that include female-headed household child-headed household disabled headed household elderly headed household very large family (8 members or more) very poor families families with chronically-ill members or having other pressing vulnerability. These criteria are adopted by the ES/NFI cluster and to a large extent are in line with vulnerabilities endorsed by other clusters in Afghanistan. ORD intends to provide winterization assistance in Paktika province which is in the priority 1 province. To reach the most vulnerable families, ORD has designed the lifesaving proposed project, which will be implemented in Paktika province (Zarghoon Shaher, Khair Kot, Jani Khil districts). ORD has a strong presence since 2018, and currently delivers the below responses under the partnership of the UN-WFP, UN-FAO, CAI, and REACH assessment for all clusters. The current 5th Reserved Allocation fund will scale up and fill the gap of ORD's current response and will be holistic and become a multi-cluster response to the vulnerable population. The current response of COVID-19, Food Security, and Education that ORD is delivering to the communities by adding the winterization package, the response will be a holistic and multi-cluster response to fill the existing gap.
ORD conducted a market assessment survey in Paktika province and recommended delivering this response in two kinds cash for fuel and heaters and in-kind for blanket packages and winter clothing kits due to the lack of quality blanket packages and winter clothing kits availability in the local market. Cash for fuel and heaters will be distributed to the ROSHAN M.paisa system which will be responsible for delivering cash to selected beneficiaries. 860 of families selected will be receiving 260$ cash for the heating equivalent in AFN as per the exchange rate during distribution in one-off installment the transfer amount will be based on the distribution plan and determined before distribution, while 860 families will receive warm winter clothing and 860 families will receive blankets in kind, in accordance to ESampNFI cluster standards.PDM will be conducted by the ORD MEAL department and the report will be shared with clusters.

title.narrative: Emergency Food Assistance to communities affected by COVID-19 in Kot and Batikot Districts of Nangarhar.

description.narrative: In line with the priorities of the AHF 5th Reserve Allocation 2020, revised HRP 2018-2021 SO1 (lives are saved in areas of highest needs), and FSAC outcome 1.3 (shock affected people (IDPs, returnees, refugees, natural disaster affected, people affected by COVID-19 and seasonaly food insecure IPC phase 3 and 4 people) of all ages have a minimum household food consumption score of above 42.5), Cordaid and partner RRAA propose cash for food to 2,620 HH (18,339 people) from communities disproportionately affected by COVID-19 in Kot and Batikot districts of Nangarhar. Cordaid will leverage the requested AHF grant with US$29,300, enabling Cordaid to cover 320 additional HH (2,300 HH covered by AHF grant and 320 HH by Cordaid private funds). The target beneficiaries are those who have experienced multiple resilience eroding shock in the past 6 months, and those subject to recent COVID-19 pressures, including lack of employment. They will receive cash for food. Following FSAC guidelines, assistance is half a food basket for a period of 2 months (US$90 in local currency) distributed in one instalment. The proposed unconditional cash assistance ensures continued, regular access to food for acute food insecure people in Kot and Batikot where people were already severely acute food insecure prior to the pandemic, but their situation has worsened by COVID-19 The proposed response is designed based on needs and gaps identified by the FSAC and 5th reserve allocation, and confirmed by recent assessments (annex A): 83% of the respondents have a poor food consumption score, 82% is applying high coping strategies. To address the acute food needs Cordaid proposes cash distribution to complement existing food stocks. Cordaid ensures that the most vulnerable people are included in the assistance, with a focus on female headed HH, HH with PWD and or where the primary breadwinner has lost employment due to COVID-19, as unemployment in the target areas is very high (71%). Beneficiary Selection Committees (BSC) will be established, conducting door-to-door assessment using the FSAC recommended tool. Markets assessments confirmed market functionality and available food, and prices are monitored. Based on cluster vulnerability criteria (household food stocks, current income, poor food consumption scores and use of more than one food-based emergency coping strategy), the most food insecure and vulnerable households will be identified by the BSCs, using the food consumption score card and rCSI. Selected beneficiaries will receive a token and will be fully informed about the assistance and how to access complaint and feedback systems, incl. Awaaz Afghanistan. Pre-distribution monitoring will be conducted as an extra verification to ensure eligibility of the beneficiaries and beneficiary lists will be shared with other actors for cross checking and avoidance of duplication. Cash will be provided through Hawala as dominated FSP in these districts. After each distribution, post distribution monitoring (PDM) will be conducted. PDMs will include questions related to risks associated with cash distribution. Cordaid/RRAA follow the FSAC guidelines for cash for food and the safer cash guidelines. Risk assessments for cash programming will be conducted and relevant risk mitigation measures will be taken to facilitate inclusive, safe and secure access of all beneficiaries (women, children, PWD, elderly) to cash assistance. Cordaid has tailored its response to a range of specific needs accounting for gender, age, disability, households headed by women, and families with specific protection needs. COVID-19 Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE) will be carried out as a cross cutting theme. Cordaid is committed to the Grand Bargain: in addition to participation, the use of cash and transparency (ReportHub IATI), Cordaid implements jointly with RRAA as part of its localization efforts and will strengthen RRAA’s capacity through training, coaching and funding

title.narrative: Emergency Food Security assistance to food insecure families in Achin and Mohmandara districts of Nangarhar province

description.narrative: The project will provide emergency response to the most vulnerable households (HHs) in Nangarhar who are food insecure as they are living under the poverty line and were already struggling to manage their minimum essential food needs, it is worsened by the loss of income/earning opportunity and thus purchasing power, as a result of COVID-19 pandemic in Afghanistan. The beneficiaries of this project are also living in recently cleared districts that are facing degraded food security situation due to long exposure to conflict. The most vulnerable people are included, specifically female headed HH, and HH with PWD and or where the primary breadwinner has lost their employment due to COVID-19. Through the proposed project Oxfam and long-term strategic partner Organization for Human Welfare (OHW) will provide cash assistance to a total of 15,000 individuals (2143 HHs) in Achin and Mohmandara districts of Nangarhar province to buy food items/commodities - these districts were recently cleared by Afghan National Forces from existence of ISIS. Based on the cluster standards and the allocation strategy paper, every eligible beneficiary HHs (those who experienced multiple resilience eroding shock in the past 6 months, and those subject to recent COVID-19 pressures, including lack of employment). they will receive half basket cash for food for 2 months (USD 90 for a period of 2 months in local currency) in one off. Cash for Food was preferred by the majority of the persons interviewed during the needs assessment since the local markets are operational. The Market Assessment confirmed that access is available and there is no restriction for both male and female while accessing/approaching market. The assessment revealed that, 40% of respondents identified cash, 18% preferred food, 6% education, 6% shelter, 25% WASH, and the rest of the 5% health facilities as first priorities. Similarly, 15% identified food, 27% cash, 25% preferred education, 11% preferred health facilities, 4% preferred shelter, and the rest 5% preferred WASH as second priorities. Oxfam’s interventions will be guided by the Integrated Food-Security Phase Classification (IPC) and Seasonal Food Security Assessment (SFSA) findings. As per IPC 2020 and SFSA, Nangarhar province was already in Crisis Situation (IPC3). Around 46% of the population in Nangarhar (1,237,262 individuals) were estimated to be at IPC3 or above during the period of April-May 2020 and 40% of the population (559,938 individuals) were estimated to be at IPC3 or above during the projection period June to November 2020. This project will support the most food-insecure population/communities in rural areas of Nangarhar Province, Achin and Mohmandara districts. FSAC identified that communities affected by COVID-19 are among the worst hit in terms of food insecurity. This project will target them so that they can survive without adopting harmful coping strategies and reduce their risk of exposure to the further shocks and build their resilience. A beneficiary selection committee using a weighted vulnerability score will be set up and also mention that post distribution monitoring (PDM) will be conducted and will include questions related to risks associated with cash distribution and efforts made to facilitate inclusive, safe and secure access of all beneficiaries (women, children, PWD, elderly) to cash assistance. COVID-19 Awareness raising messages developed by Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) with the support of World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF in the languages of Afghanistan will be used for this purpose. Oxfam will integrate conflict sensitivity into the action, by conducting context and conflict analysis of the target areas. This is especially important as cash assistance can work as potential flashpoint in creating new conflict or exacerbating existing tensions. The grant of USD 300,000 will provide immediate response and save lives of 15,000 persons (USD 20 per person).

title.narrative: Emergency Food Assistance to Communities affected by COVID-19 in Arghistan, Miwand, and Nesh District of Kandahar

description.narrative:
The project will provide emergency response to the potentially vulnerable household (HHS) in Arghistan, Nesh, and Miwand districts of Kandahar province who are food insecure as they are living under the poverty line and experienced various multiple resilience eroding shock in the past six (6) months, and those subject to recent COVID-19 pressured, including loss of employment. These people were already struggling to manage their minimum food requirements, their situation is worsened by the loss of income/ earning opportunity and thus, purchasing power, as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic in Afghanistan. As a consequence of the pandemic, complete lockdown measures have been imposed in the entire Kandahar province resulted in daily wage opportunities and small trader income to significantly decrease.
ANCC will provide a two months half basket cash for food assistance to a total of 20,000 individuals (2,857) household (HHS) in three districts (Arghistan, Nesh, and Maywand) of Kandahar province. Based on the cluster standards package, every eligible HH will receive USD 90. This amount is based on the FSAC endorsed standard package (calculated based on 2,100 kcal/person/day food needs of an average size family and the market price of food items). ANCC will carry out market price monitoring prior to distribution to verify the feasibility and appropriateness of the ash amount. Most of the time, cash for food is preferred by vulnerable populations. As per field information in terms of the market, access is available in all districts. The Arghistan district is blocked to Kandahar city but the trader imports the food commodities from Spin-Boldak district.
.The COVID-19 lockdown and crisis have resulted in a serious and sustained impact on Kandahar and all Afghanistan’s economy. Recovery is expected to take several years, with new investment constrained by political uncertainties, continued insecurity, and question around ongoing international support. This project will support the most food-insecure population of the above-mentioned three districts. The COVID-19 has resulted to further deteriorate the food security situation of the lower-income population. This project will target them so that they can survive without adopting negative coping strategies and fulfill their daily food consumption to address the obstacles.
Protection will be integrated across the project cycle by raising awareness among the women and men about their rights. Women’s rights will be discussed in-country context, gender-based violence (GBV) impacts, measures to mitigate GBV, and ways of getting support in case of rights violations, GBV, or other protection concerns. The women and men of the selected HHS will also be made aware of COVID-19 risks, prevention methods, and other crucial information in this regard. This will be done with no additional cost except staff time. COVID-19 awareness-raising messages developed by the Ministry of Public health (MoPH) with support of the World Health Organization and UNICEF in the local languages.
ANCC will also carry out the risk analysis by conducting context and conflict analysis of the anticipated areas. This is all for better implementation of the project and security of cash assistance to be distributed to the potentially vulnerable and marginalized segment.

title.narrative: Protection response to GBV survivors in Herat and Helmand

description.narrative: The areas targeted under this project already had protection concerns and that has significantly increased in the COVID-19 pandemic situation and associated lockdown. Oxfam and OWH proposes a structured and timely response to the increased protection needs of IDPs, returnees and host communities in Herat and Helmand provinces of Afghanistan. Oxfam aims to assist 38,320 individuals (15,328 women, 11,496 men, 7664 girls and 3832 boys) who are severely affected by conflicts, flood, drought and Covid-19, by providing protection and Gender Based Violence (GBV) services which include a multisector response (legal, safety, health and psychosocial) through door-to door outreach and referrals that facilitate community based specialized services. Women and girls’ survivors are provided with dignity kits in Women Friendly Health Spaces (WFHS), information dissemination through media broadcasts on women rights to increase awareness, GBV and case management, referral and follow up of protection cases. Oxfam will adopt an integrated approach, leveraging protection activities aligned with the priorities laid out in the AHF 5th Reserve Allocation-2020 with the eventual objective of recovery and resilience-building in the target communities. Provision of immediate protection assistance will alleviate suffering of beneficiaries in a gender sensitive manner and increase their resilience. The protection activities based on identified needs on the ground will be implemented in Hirat Province: (Kush e Robat Sangi , Zinda Jan, Adrakshan amp Ghoryan) and Helmand Province: (Nad Ali, Grishk, Lashkar Gah and Nawe Barakzai) The main objectives of the project are to: save lives, alleviate suffering and protect human dignity for the most vulnerable, support people to build their resilience and increase capacity on human rights and women’s rights to reduce protection violations, are reduced and respect for international humanitarian law(IHL) is increased through protection services. Oxfam’s protection program provides practical protection support, through Women Friendly Health Spaces (WFHS), psychosocial, legal services, referral of beneficiaries with protection concerns to other service providers, door to door mobile outreach and community based right information dissemination. Oxfam amp OHW has achieved concrete successes in environments such as Herat and Helmand provinces and has an established presence in these provinces while to build on this work, Oxfam will use the AHF 5th Reserved Allocation-2020-21 funding to increase the scope and scale of its protection activities, and to conduct broaden right awareness through media broadcasting in TV/radio programming to a wider population. AHF 5th RA 2020-21’s contribution to this project will support returnees, displaced and host communities to undertake protection services ( Psychosocial/Legal, referrals amp follow up of protection cases, community right awareness raising, mobile outreach and train community based protection committees (CBPC) for sustainability of the project. Oxfam amp OWH will provide training and sensitization on International Humanitarian law (IHL) and protection to a majority of individuals in the affected communities whom are unaware of the available referral systems and GBV mitigation strategies in order to increase awareness on GBV risks, available referral pathways and mitigation strategies. Oxfam and OHW will establish 4 women friendly health spaces, community dialogues and mobile community outreach which will support protection responses in wider communities.

title.narrative: Essential life saving trauma care and COVID-19 response services in selected districts of six provinces of Nangarhar, Kunar, Laghman, Kunduz, Baghlan and Kapisa

description.narrative:
The project is aimed to provide (1) essential emergency health services consisting of trauma care and COVID-19 response in high priority areas of the three eastern provinces – Nangarhar, Kunar and Laghman and (2) essential protection and COVID-19 response services in Kunduz, Baghlan and Kapisa provinces. All of the target provinces are hard-hit by the current COVID-19 outbreak, and the security situation in all provinces have negatively impacted people’s access to services. The complex security situation in the eastern region have increased the incidence and consequent risks of trauma cases as mobility of people is limited and the existing public health facilities are trying to somehow respond to the COVID-19 situation bringing other health conditions (such as trauma care) to second priority. In the three eastern provinces (Nangarhar, Kunar and Laghman), the primary focus of the project will be to make available trauma care services through the existing BPHS health facilities and to strengthen the uptake and management capacity of Nangarhar Regional Hospital (NRH) which is the main tertiary level facility in the eastern province. The trauma care services will be in the form of First Aid Trauma Posts (FATPs) established in the following health facilities. Kunar province: - Noorgal CHC (Noorgal district) - Saw PHC (Narai district) Laghman province: - Dawlat Shah CHC (Dawlat Shah district) - Alokhail BHC (Alingar district) In the three eastern provinces, the COVID-19 response services will be provided through the establishment and operation of COVID-19 MHPSS Outreach Teams tasked with two major objectives: (1) to provide mental health and psychosocial support services (MHPSS) to IDPs, host communities and shock-affected non-displaced communities and (2) to carry out risk communication and community engagement (RCCE) activities in line with the RCCE WG list of activities. A total of 5 COVID-19 MHPSS Outreach Teams will provide the mentioned services with specific geographical assignment as below: - Kunar Team-1 covering Noorgal and Khas Kunar districts - Kunar Team-2 covering Chawkai and Narang districts - Kunar Team-3 covering Asadabad, Watapur, and Sarkani districts - Laghman Team-1 covering Mehtherlam/Badpakh districts - Laghman Team-2 covering Alingar and Qarghayee districts
In the provinces of Kunduz, Baghlan and Kapisa, the modality of protection services provision will consist of the PSS and RCCE services provided through the planned 8 PSS Outreach Teams, and the remote telephonic consultations by experienced psychosocial counselors (PSCs) stationed in Kunduz (2 PSCs covering Kunduz and Baghlan provinces) and Mahmood-e-Raqi cities (2 PSCs covering Kapisa province). Secondly, general awareness of people in the three provinces will be raised through COVID-19 focused TV and radio spots in view of standard MoPH messages. Further, stress management to BPHS and EPHS health facilities staff in the three provinces will be an integral part of the project.
The health-related activities in three eastern provinces (Nangarhar, Kunar and Laghman) will be for 12 months, while the protection-related activities in Kunduz, Baghlan and Kapisa will be for 6 months.

title.narrative: Emergency Primary Health Care Services and COVID Response for Externally displaced population in khost province

description.narrative: After 40 years of war, natural disasters amp persistent poverty, the afghans have to deal with another deadly blow from COVID19. It is almost 09 months since the virus’ emergence, its humanitarian consequences are now affecting every aspect of life amp threatening the survival amp well-being of the most vulnerable by creating new needs amp exacerbating existing ones. People’s living conditions, emotional amp physical reserves, amp their overall resilience in the face of recurrent shocks have been eroded by decades of hardship. Inability to access basic services is a key consequence of the on-going crisis amp is a product of a range of factors including conflict, insecurity amp fear, poverty amp under-investment in critical infrastructure amp human resources. The country is also facing a protection crisis where people’s rights to safety, security amp well-being are threatened by an increase in the conflict amp by the economic implications of COVID-19 also. Externally displaced population (EDPs) from North Waziristan living in the Gulan Camp(Gurbuz) , Matun, Tani amp Spera Districts (Khost) are highly vulnerable due to poor access to basic facilities including health services amp the pandemic have worsen their situation especially at this time when the current health structure are overburdened amp resource drained. To support amp fill the gap in the current health structure of the MoPH, Johanniter International Assistance (JUH) amp its implementing partner- Humanitarian Assistance ampDevelopment Association for Afghanistan (HADAAF) will jointly implement the project in Gulan Camp(Gurbuz), Matun, Tani amp Spira districts, to improve access of EDPs amp nearby living host communities to life saving health services amp contain the spread of COVID 19 in the communities to reduce mortality amp morbidity rate. Following interventions will be implemented 1) Provision of Primary Health Care, Mental Health/ PSS services amp COVID screening in Gulan Camp through the CHC 2) Emergency Mobile Health Services ,COVID screening amp PSC for suspected COVID cases in hard to reach areas in Tani, Spira ampMatun 3) PSC through telephone amp follow up of suspected amp confirmed COVID cases who are quarantined in their homes amp those in isolation/treatment centers 4) Train health shura amp community leaders in RCCE 5) Community outreach amp awareness raising on the prevention of COVID 19 community transmission 6)Provision of PPEs, Chlorine amp Spraying Pumps to HFs staff to disinfect amp prevent infection so they can safely continue providing services to the affected population. The project interventions are in line with the HC priorities which is to support risk communication intervention to ensure messaging on COVID-19 is widely available to all in Afghanistan, Reduce avoidable morbidity, mortality, amp disability due to emergency health condition among returnees ,migrants amp displaced amp underserved, hard to reach communities through provision of direct healthcare services amp contribute in strengthening public health care systems through operational support of selected health care facilities in coordination with Provincial Public Health Directorate (PPHD) and, improve disease prevention , proper hygiene practices among affected amp vulnerable host communities as well as health care personnel through community-based amp self-help interventions. The project will jointly be implemented by the partners, The JUH Country Office will provide technical support to the sub-implementing partner, continuously monitor project activities amp will support procurement of medicine, equipment amp lead capacity building of staff amp community elders during the project implementation. This way the project will be launched and implemented smoothly, where HADAAF with technical support of JUHwill focus on project implementation in a coordinated way at provincial and community level. This intervention is planned for 12 months with 1 month inception period. Project reports will regularly be shared with all stakeholders (KBL/KHT)

description.narrative: CARE Afghanistan proposes to meet the emergency needs of 9300 vulnerable households (65,100 individuals) potentially to be affected by COVID-19 in at-risk communities of IDPs, informal settlement, and marginalized communities in 7 districts across the provinces of Kabul and Balkh. The project will support the target communities through (1) deployment of 7 mobile health teams to provide: Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE) service about COVID-19 services including access to Information, Education and Communication (IEC) materials, training of the community influential, awareness-raising session and strong community engagement on COVID-19 community- based surveillance of COVID-19 cases, identification of suspected cases, home-based treatment of the mild cases and referral of the high-risk cases provision of life-saving Primary Health Care (PHC) services with a specific focus on women and children provision of psycho social counseling and awareness-raising to reduce fear, rumors and stigma among affected communities. (2) Provision of technical guidance and dissemination of guidelines on COVID-19 to health facilities including case definition and case management to BPHS, EPHS, and private health facilities and surveillance teams as CARE has a long presence in the two provinces of Kabul and Balkh and implemented various health and humanitarian projects. title.narrative: Inclusive COVID-19 Emergency WASH Response in Hard-to-Reach Areas of Badakhshan and Kunduz

description.narrative:
In Afghanistan, the pandemic comes at a time when the country is grappling with deadly conflict, severe food insecurity, and a dire economy that has plunged over 80% of the population below the poverty line (C-19 MSHCP). Existing WASH services including water and sanitation facilities were already unable to adequately support escalating WASH needs from conflict and natural disasters, without the added burden of COVID-19. According to IOM, the number of confirmed cases suggests that Afghanistan could have one of the highest infection rates in the world, with the Ministry of Public Health projecting over 25.6 million Afghans will be infected with the virus if serious action is not undertaken. With over 60% of COVID-19 tests allocated to just three of the country’s 34 provinces, humanitarian agencies continue to voice a lack of attention and support to other increasingly vulnerable areas. Accordingly, Kunduz and Badakhshan Provinces―the proposed area of intervention―have largely been neglected in terms of both testing and response, with 1,040 confirmed cases considered a severe underrepresentation of the current context (MoPH, 9/15/20). The lack of confirmed cases combined with rumors and limited access to reliable information have created a false sense of security, prompting communities to disregard vital prevention measures required to mitigate or reduce the likelihood of an outbreak.
Through a whole of community approach, Concern Worldwide is proposing inclusive and accessible COVID-19 emergency response in underserved, hard-to-reach areas of Yaftal and Arghanch Khwa districts of Badakhshan and Khanabad and Aliabad districts of Kunduz, entailing: 1) the installation of age, gender, and disability-inclusive handwashing stations at remote health care facilities and public gathering areas 2) the rehabilitation of damaged village hand pump wells that are safe and accessible to different vulnerability groups and 3) the targeted construction of safe and appropriate latrines for disabled and female-headed households. Specifically, Concern will install 960 communal handwashing stations at pre-identified vulnerable sites of target communities, taking into consideration age, gender, and disability access to ensure equal assistance. This includes sex-segregated facilities (where applicable), soak pits for water drainage, and an appropriate height for comfortable access and use by children, elderly, and people with a disability. Handwashing stations will be provided alongside a three-month supply of liquid soap, and will require the signing of an MoU that details sustained community-led maintenance and management, including proper transportation and storage of water. Additionally, through a community-based participatory approach, Concern will identify and rehabilitate 80 damaged hand pump wells that are accessible and safe for the whole community in order to address the prevalent lack of access to clean water. Existing CBOs, community leaders, and representatives of MRRD will be involved in the site selection process to ensure local buy-in and sustainability of the repaired infrastructure. Guided by inclusive Beneficiary Selection Committees (BSCs), Concern will identify 415 disabled and female-headed households that lack able-bodied members for the construction of sanitary latrines. Concern will abide by UNHCR’s protection checklist for sanitation facilities, including a safe location, proper lighting, minimum space standards, and locks on the inside for privacy and safety. Throughout project implementation, Concern will mainstream COVID-19 risk communication and awareness campaigns, including gender-sensitive hygiene promotion, rumor management, contextual mitigation measures, and available channels for health support. The timely provision of the WASH minimum package will establish the conditions that allow 63,720 people to live with good health, dignity, and comfort―which is particularly crucial in the context of a pandemic.

title.narrative: Procurement and Prepositioning of Core Supplies for WASH Response

description.narrative:
The COVID 19 Pandemic has significantly affected Afghanistan due to its weak health system and limited capacity to prevent the spread of the virus. High internal displacement and a weak water and sanitation infrastructure worsen the situation. A new wave of the virus feared to come during the winter of 2020 could add significantly to the agony of an Afghan population already grappling with the economic impact of the virus. According to the Afghanistan Humanitarian Response Plan (June 2020 update) as many as 35 million Afghans are in need of a social safety net, 14 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance, while 7.2 million of those are in need of water, sanitation and hygiene assistance specifically.
DACAAR directly contributes to this plan and to the containment of the COVID-19 outbreak as well as to improving the overall WASH condition of at risk populations by procuring, prepositioning and making available handwashing soap as a core WASH pipeline supply in support of WASH Cluster partner response projects.
Handwashing with soap is considered as one of the most effective containment strategies for COVID 19 available to at risk populations. Procuring and supplying soap as a standalone hygiene item will be swift and will add to the agility of response by WASH partners. Given that this is a stockpiling project and the distribution of the supplies will be undertaken by other WASH partners, the target beneficiaries will not be assisted by DACAAR but by partners. DACAAR will report on the beneficiaries based on reports from WASH partners who accessed the stockpiles. Distribution by WASH partners to at risk families will be based on the Sphere Standard of a minimum of 250grams of soap per person per month. DACAAR will procure and preposition 651,000 bars of 130gram high quality anti-septic soap sufficient for 3 months use for 15,500 at risk families (108,500 individuals).
The soap supplies will be stocked in the following strategic geographical hubs: Kabul, Kandahar city Herat city Mazar-e-Sharif city Kunduz city Maimana city (Faryab) and in Talugan city (Takhar), with the potential of being moved to locations where need is greatest. These locations are central enough to be accessed by partners implementing WASH projects in the provinces prioritized in the AHF 5th reserve allocation strategy namely Badghis, Herat, Faryab, Zabul, Badakhshan, Nimroz, Kunduz and Jawzjan as well as from other provinces of the country. DACAAR will maintain sufficient flexibility to transfer supplies among the warehouses. Partners can readily access available stock of soap for use in their response projects based on approval from the WASH Cluster.
Procurement of the soap will be performed as part of a comprehensive Invitation to Bed (ITB) process following DACAAR procurement procedures (attached) which is line with AHF procurement regulations. The ITB process will include a market assessment enabling DACAAR to identify and contract the cheapest bidder who can deliver the highest quality soap. Procured soap will be checked stringently to ensure highest anti-septic quality (given recent lessons learned from the sector on fake Dettol soap in the market). The following will be performed during the ITB to ensure quality of soap procured - Physical Description : - Based on experience and technical knowhow , the assigned technical colleagues know the physical attribute of the quality soap required and check the delivered soap accordingly.
- Industrial Standards Certificate/ Proving Documents: - The bidders are usually asked for the required documents. A Sample is attached.
- Legal Import: - DACAAR buys legally imported Antiseptic Dettol Soap having proper custom clearance documents.
In addition to the above, DACAAR will reserve the right to perform laboratory examiniation of the soap with the help of Afghanistan National Standards Authority (ANSA).

Children in Crisis is requesting $250K to mount a rapid response to mitigate and respond to the protection risks related to the current crisis and to increase access to essential information, supplies and services for 16000 conflict and crisis-affected individuals across Badakhshan, Bamiyan, Kabul and Paktika provinces. The strategic selection of these activities is intended to respond to protection risks of children in the immediate term compounded by the current crises, whilst building sustainable institutions to increase communities’ resilience to the long term, embedded protection risks for at risk children and the wider group of children. The project uses a scaffolded intervention that intensifies support and services across categories of increasing vulnerabilities: 2500 vulnerable households with more than four children, identified through vulnerability and needs assessment will receive essential life-saving winterization kits to support the children of households by providing warm clothes and blankets, that supports them to continue attending school, and interact with other children in public space during the winter season. 56 vulnerable communities shall benefit from the functional community based protection committees which shall be trained to mitigate and respond to protection risks of individuals and groups in the community 2900 vulnerable children (including children at significant risk: UASC, CAAFAG, street children, GBV survivors) shall benefit from the direct referrals and supplementary services provided by Children in Crisis. Specifically, 250 UASC children at significant risk due to separation from caregivers will receive counselling and case management services and 250 children at severe risk of exposure to exploitation and violence will receive specialized services including interim care, case management and family tracing and reunification.
Children in Crisis [CiC] is a protection sector specialist, recognized as one of the “Top Ten NGO” actors by the Child Protection Action Network [CPAN] in 2019. Our extensive experience and expertise in protection programming – with proven approaches to working with incarcerated children – positions us to implement an intensive intervention over a six-month project period. At present, CIC also operates an Education in Emergencies intervention targeting 3500 conflict-affected children in Uruzgan under the Afghanistan Humanitarian Fund approx. 20% of this intervention includes integrated protection activities that underscore our sustained commitment and capabilities in protection.

title.narrative: Comprehensive Winterisation Response in Underserved Communities of Kunduz and Takhar

description.narrative:
Due to the economic impact of COVID-19, an estimated 1.3 million Afghans will not have access to heating and fuel this winter, leaving them extremely vulnerable to below freezing temperatures (Joint Winterisation Strategy Afghanistan, 2020). In high altitude areas with cold climates and harsh weather conditions, lives are at risk within one day of exposure to the elements. Families may be pushed to employ negative coping mechanisms, which can often have serious protection implications for women and children.
In response, Concern Worldwide is proposing urgent and time-sensitive winterisation assistance to address the severe NFI needs of acutely vulnerable host, IDPs and returnee populations of Kunduz and Takhar provinces. The proposed target districts―Namakab and Chal of Takhar and Aqtash of Kunduz―were identified based on the agency’s demonstrated operational capacity and access, coordination with other humanitarian actors in the area, severity of winterisation needs, and lack of previous assistance. Specifically, Concern is prepared to respond to the critical NFI needs of 959 acutely vulnerable families with a comprehensive winterisation package of i) 3-month heating/fuel cash assistance ($200 per family) ii) in-kind standard blanket packages ($40 value per family) and iii) in-kind winter clothing kits ($65 value per family). The use of cash for heating and fuel support, backed by recent market assessments, PDMs, and REACH evaluations, provides families with the flexibility to purchase the most appropriate appliances for their specific shelter type. This includes a gas cylinder or Bukhari stove and 180 Kg of firewood or LPG. The provision of in-kind blanket packages and winter clothing kits will keep the immediate space around bodies warm, and significantly help vulnerable families cope with the winter season. While these items are intended to be distributed jointly, households that do not meet the criteria for all three packages will only receive the relevant assistance. Given the time-sensitive nature of this response, with winter quickly approaching, Concern will distribute the mentioned support via a single instalment.
During assessments and distributions, Concern will mainstream COVID-19 risk communication and awareness campaigns―including COVID-19 kits and hygiene promotion within winter sectorial response―as well as gender-sensitive behavioral change messaging to positively influence expenditure choices and coping strategies. Since the distribution is conducted in an closed space during winter, Concern will ensure to limit the number of beneficiaries per distribution and will provide masks to beneficiaries as well as project staff. Sanitizers will be procured to utilize by the beneficiaries and staff during the distribution. Gender, age, and disability considerations will be integrated as much as possible to ensure the response is inclusive to all segments of a community, particularly People with Specific Needs (PSNs). Winterisation response will place special attention towards children, the elderly, chronically ill, or those with limited mobility to deliver lifesaving insulation support to the most at-risk groups.

Total 2248 (2023 from AHF and 225 from Cordaid funds) HH will be covered from the project. In Kunduz (Kunduz City, Iman Sahib and Khan Abad) Cordaid will target 1,448 (1225 recently displaced HH who are assessed by Cordaid in October under START Funds and 223 new host) out of 1448 HH 225 2ill covered by Cordaid funding . Nearly 1/5 of the HH reported having at least 1 member with a disability or chronic illness (REACH ESampNFI Winterization evaluation 2019-2020). Because of high coping strategies (82% of the respondents are resorting to negative coping mechanisms) combined with the majority of the people (83%) having a poor food consumption score and 99% having no food stocks at all, people in the assessed districts are severely and acute food insecure. With winter arriving soon, the respondents raised the need for heating materials (69% of the respondents), warm clothes (87%) and blankets (49%). With reduced income, increase in cost of living and limited job opportunities (80% and 67% is unemployed in Kunduz and Nangarhar respectively) people lack the means to protect themselves against winter and are likely to resort to negative coping strategies to keep themselves warm this winter. The cash will be provided for heating materials because of market functionality. The blanket will be deliver to the beneficiary because of the bulk procurement and will cost us lower the then local markets . Cordaid is leveraging US$ 54,495 from its own funds to the project to reach more people. title.narrative: Winterization Assistance for Vulnerable Households in Daykundi and Samangan

description.narrative:
According to the Joint Winterization Strategy (dated July 2020) and ESNFI cluster data, 504,000 people in Daykundi and 448,000 people in Samangan will be exposed to harsh winter weather in the coming winter season. The Covid-19 pandemic has led to widespread illness and mortality, a deep economic recession, and starkly reduced income opportunities in these provinces, which in turn has depleted productive assets and reduced communities’ capacity to cope with shocks. Afghanaid’s recent needs assessment (Annex A) found that the vast majority of households in both provinces are unable to cover their basic needs and require urgent assistance.
In line with ESNFI cluster priorities detailed in the Joint Winterization Strategy, Afghanaid proposes to provide crucial heating and blanket assistance to 2127 vulnerable households in Aybak and Hazrat-e Sultan districts of Samangan, and Sang-e Takht, Khedir and Ishterlay districts of Daykundi, which are all prioritized by the ESNFI cluster under this allocation. Based on communities’ preference for cash transfers and a recent market assessment (Annex B) confirming community access to well-functioning markets, Afghanaid proposes cash as the modality for heating assistance. In line with cluster preferences, cash assistance will be complemented with in-kind assistance 25% of the most vulnerable targeted households (187 in Samangan and 359 in Daykundi) will also receive in-kind blanket packages.
In Samangan, the intervention will provide 280 households in Aybak and 468 in Hazrat-e Sultan with a standard 3-month heating package of US$200 per household, and 187 of these households will also receive an in-kind blanket package consisting of three double-sized blankets in line with cluster standards. In Daykundi, Afghanaid will provide 500 households in Sang-e Takht, 500 in Khedir and 379 in Ishterlay with standard 4-month heating packages of US$260 per household, and 359 of these households will also receive an in-kind blanket package. In Sang-e Takht and Khedir, the proposed winterization response will be complemented with a FSAC-funded cash for food intervention, ensuring that vulnerable households’ multiple needs are met in these areas of great need.
Afghanaid will establish participant selection and distribution committees including representatives from local communities (e.g. CDC and DDA heads), government (e.g. ANDMA and DoRR) and Afghanaid. Participants will be selected according to ESNFI vulnerability criteria to ensure the most acutely in need are targeted, including IDPs, women-headed households and households with a large number of dependent children.
The project team will work with a reliable saraf in each province to distribute the heating cash from central distribution points in a single tranche to ensure that assistance reaches the participants as soon as possible. Participants with limited mobility will be brought to the distribution point or receive the assistance at home.
Afghanaid is well placed to implement this project, with several years of presence in Daykundi, current operations in the target district and excellent access and strong relationships with communities as well as district and provincial authorities. Afghanaid has extensive experience in humanitarian programming, with current and recent humanitarian assistance projects in multiple provinces including Daykundi, funded by AHF, WFP, FAO, and ECHO. The projects include emergency food, livelihoods, winterization, and shelter assistance, using both in-kind and cash modalities.
This intervention will provide 14,889 vulnerable men, women, boys and girls with crucial heating and blankets, reducing illness and mortality and increasing participants’ capacity to rebuild their livelihoods by avoiding the sale of productive assets, so that they are more resilient against future shocks.

title.narrative: Provision of immediate winterization assistance to people in need in high priority location of Khost province.

description.narrative: CAHPO’s proposed intervention is an emergency delivery measure intended to ensure a timely and effective response to humanitarian needs arising from conflicts, natural disasters, and other emergencies in the south-eastern region of Afghanistan (Khost province with is the 2nd priority in the winterization strategy). The intervention will focus on meeting the urgent humanitarian needs of internally displaced people and families within the targeted provinces of Khost as well as those fleeing to this province to seek shelter from outstanding challenges in adjacent provinces. Through implementation of the proposed project, CAHPO intended to support 1,135 affected families in Khost province to save their lives through provision of winterization support such as heating fuel/gas, winter clothing and blankets. CAHPO targets a total of 7,945 beneficiaries (2,660 individuals in Gurbaz district, 2,730 in Tanay district and 2,555 individuals in Nadirshakot district) for all three types of activities such as Winter Clothing, Blankets and heating materials. The number of beneficiaries for each type of activity will be determined based on the initial assessment in these three districts. CAHPO will determined the type of heating materials (Gas stove, fuel/gas) based on the findings from the assessment in each location with USD 200 per family. Providing heating support in kind is more favorable for many vulnerable families such as disabled or female-headed families in the target areas. Moreover, in-kind heating can be valuable for filing a winterization gap at a crucial time (without spending time by families to buy and transfer heating items). CAHPO will contract at the nearest possible level to distribute/provide the heating materials to the selected families. CAHPO will conduct an assessment to identify the needs of selected beneficiary for the mentioned assistances with a proper categorization for heating stove with fuel/gas, clothes and blankets. CAHPO will ensure that the most vulnerable people in need are prioritized for the winterization using selected criteria, including female-headed household child-headed household disabled headed household elderly headed household very large family (8 members or more) very poor families families with chronically- ill members or having other pressing vulnerability. The winterization items will be procured under the supervision of committee and will be delivered to identified beneficiaries by the distribution committee. CAHPO will properly coordinate the implementation process with all actors in the area as it was coordinated in the planning stage. A post-distribution monitoring will be conducted with a sample of beneficiary households. Furthermore, CAHPO will ensure that any negative impact that the project could have on women, men and children will be timely identified and addressed by the project team. The proposed activities and locations were coordinated through relevant ESNFI and AHF partners during the concept note submission to avoid duplication of services. Coordination will be continued throughout the project cycle at various levels. CAHPO has a presence in Khost since 2013 and implemented projects in past and created active social networks among the community for humanitarian and development purposes which will contribute to the effective implementation of the project. Since the assistances under this project is delivered during the COVID-19 pandemic, all measures and WHO COVID-19 and Health sector guidance will be considered during the implementation. CAHPO is currently reviewing internal available resources if we could provide additional support to more vulnerable families. CAHPO will keep informed the clusters and AHF if our internal resources can provide additional assistances. However, using our internal resources, there will be contribution from CAHPO staff at national/provincial levels who have not been allocated under this project.

title.narrative: Food assistance to the vulnerable population in Kamdish district of Nuristan Province

description.narrative:
Information provided by REACH and the Afghanistan Food Security Outlook Update August 2020 (based on data from FEWS network) shows that as a result of overall insufficient income due to prolonged impacts of conflict on livelihood activities, the majority of poor rural households are expected to be unable to meet all essential food needs. The overall needs assessment shows a prediction of 40% of the population living in IPC 3 or IPC 4 food security situation during coming winter.
In line with the AHF and adapted HRP 2020, ZOA-SHPOUL will provide food assistance through the implementation of cash for food project in Kamdesh district of Nuristan. The intervention will be through restricted and unconditional cash distribution. Cash will be distributed in 2 installments of USD 90 to cover 50% of the minimum food basket for 4 months. This modality is chosen as it empowers beneficiaries to have more control over their own resources which will maintain their dignity as they have a choice.
1072 HHs with a total of 7500 beneficiaries in Kamdesh will receive four half food package distribution through cash for food package. The provision will be in two installments in order to be most cost effective and to avoid the distributions being hindered by heavy snowfall. A proven Hawala will facilitate the distribution at Barikot,a village belonging to the Narai district. It has been the usual distribution point in the past and has proven to work well, beneficiaries are able to travel to that point. The distribution will be done based on the signed lists and/or tokens issued to the selected beneficiaries by the Beneficiary Selection Committee (BSC) through the Hawala system. In Kamdesh the network coverage is less than 20% hence more than 80% of the beneficiaries will not be able to make use of the phone. Representatives of the Community Development Committee (CDC) consisting of 10 ‘senior’ community members (F/M) will be involved in contacting beneficiaries if needed and NIDs will be checked. The cash distribution covers 50% of the accepted monthly MEB for an average Afghan family, it is expected that families will be able to cover the remaining needs. Information will be shared regarding the required food items to be purchased.
Besides the cash distribution, community mobilizers conduct awareness training on COVID-19, and how to potentially mitigate Sexual Gender-Based Violence (SGBV), and Domestic Violence (DV) in the families, including a focus on child rights. Awareness raising will take place in all villages in separate male/female groups, female beneficiaries receive the hygiene kit. Information leaflets will be distributed to ensure ongoing access to information.
Covid-19 and Protection awareness-raising sessions also take place at the distribution site. Key people of each village participate in community dialogues in order to discuss protection issues and information will be shared about other services available within the area to enable women to potentially get in touch with support services. This will however continue to be a challenge due to the remoteness and small number of health facilities available.
Kamdesh has small shops in some of the villages, these shops cannot fulfill the demand for the required food items. The market assessment done by SHPOUL local staff was focused on the market of Narai, a district in Kunar Province which touches Kamdesh. The market in Narai is able to deal with the demand for food items, the population of Kamdesh usually purchases their food items there. The market is accessible on foot, donkey, and the occasional car. The communities are stable hence social cohesion is reasonably strong through which community members support each other, in particular the elderly, people with disabilities, and female-headed households. For Female/children/elderly/PWD headed households the distribution will take place at Kamdesh centre to ensure a safe and secure distribution accessible to all.

title.narrative: Provision of emergency cash for food assistance in Samangan province

description.narrative:
Through this project, ACTED will provide immediate life-saving food security assistance to 13,104 vulnerable and food insecure beneficiaries (1,872 households) in Samangan province.
The humanitarian situation in Afghanistan continues to steadily decline in late 2020, characterized by high levels of ongoing violence and conflict, natural disasters, high rates of poverty, and the COVID-19 pandemic, which have contributed to worsen the grave protection crisis and cause significant displacement and high multi-sector needs across the country. Populations are characterized by low resilience and high vulnerabilities and often fall into a state of acute emergency and need urgent support to meet their immediate basic needs. The COVID-19 pandemic in particular has had a significant acute impact across Afghanistan, and exacerbated already high levels of multi-sector needs for vulnerable communities due to loss of livelihoods and income, and reduced access to essential services as a result of government imposed lockdowns, movement restrictions and market volatility, which has eroded coping mechanisms and increased negative coping strategies.
Within this context, food insecurity remains severe across Afghanistan, and has worsened due to COVID-19. Most notably, the socio-economic impact of COVID-19 is having a devastating impact on people’s livelihoods and income, and coupled with chronic underlying poverty, has already started to further challenge families’ capacity to purchase essential food supplies. The lockdown and restrictions of mobility has had a negative impact on both the supply chain for basic commodities as well as on household livelihood and income opportunities, subjecting vulnerable households to reduced income, higher prices of food commodities, and reduced access to food due to supply chain disruptions. Samangan province is specifically facing this worsening situation. The latest IPC analysis projects Samangan as escalating to IPC Phase 4 (Emergency) from November 2020 to March 2021, and it is projected to have 40% of its urban population either in Phase 3 (Crisis) or 4 (Emergency).
ACTED is uniquely positioned to provide immediate food security cash assistance support vulnerable households in Samangan province and will provide cash assistance to cover four months half food ration (45 USD per HH per month x 4 months) to the most vulnerable beneficiaries to help support them during the lean season. In total, ACTED will target 872 households in Khuram wa Sarbagh districts and 1,000 households in Ruy-e-Duab district with cash assistance. The cash assistance will be heavily linked with and complemented by multi-sector responses, especially winterization assistance, in order to ensure that beneficiaries’ high multi-sector needs (particularly in winterization, health and WASH through various other funding streams, including another AHF allocation) are met and addressed during the winter months, and that the unconditional cash for food assistance will contribute to meeting their food needs.

title.narrative: Lifesaving intervention for multiple shock affected population at risk of hunger and malnutrition through cash for food distribution in Ghor Province, Afghanistan

description.narrative:
The proposed action’s objective is to improve the food security status of multiple-shock-affected population and mitigate their risk to face malnutrition through cash for food assistance during the harsh winter and lean season in Dawlatyar and Lal Wa Sarjangal districts of Ghor Province.
Ghor Province is, according to all the assessments done in Afghanistan (HNO/HRP 2020, SFSA, IPC, FEWSNET) one of the most affected provinces in Afghanistan in terms of food insecurity. Mostly mountainous with limited arable land, Ghor has the highest deficit of wheat in the country. This province has the history of being classified in Emergency Phase (IPC Phase 4) during the past years. As of IPC September 2020 Analysis, Ghor province had 25% of its population in IPC 4 and 35% of its population in IPC 3.
COVID-19 also has had an impact on this already fragile province. Unusually high food prices linked to border closures and panic buying, caused by COVID-19, further exacerbated food access of households already living below the poverty line. Food commodity prices have increased to between 10% and 20% (IPC analysis April-November 2020 and WFP market monitoring 2019-2020). Moreover, it is expected that the food security situation in Ghor will further deteriorate with the arrival of the winter. As the harvest season is over, labor and job opportunities will decrease and the purchasing power of the local population will drastically drop. This along with the peak in food prices due to the heavy snowfall blocking the roads will severely limit the access to diversified food during the harsh months of winter.
To address the emergency food insecurity situation in Ghor Province, AAH will deliver cash for food of the equivalent of 4 half rations for 17,000 individuals. These 17,000 individuals will be provided with unrestricted and unconditional cash. However, strong sensitization will be done by AAH teams before and during the distributions about food diversity to encourage households to spend their cash on diversified and highly nutritious food. This will prevent the households to engage in negative coping strategies that may result in loss of essential livelihood assets and therefore, increase their food consumption and dietary diversity.
The expected impact of this cash-based intervention is that vulnerable households do not exhaust their harvest during the lean season and have uninterrupted access to diversified food during the upcoming harsh months of winter, avoiding a further deterioration of their food security status.
This will be a six-month project, from 1st of December 2020 until 31st of May 2021, just before the start of the harvest in Ghor Province.

title.narrative: Emergency Food Assistance through cash distribution in Hazrat-e-Sultan district of Samangan province.

description.narrative: Afghanistan remains one of the most vulnerable countries in the world. A complex and protracted conflict, the effects of climate change, demographic shifts, limited employment opportunities, pervasive gender inequalities and slow progress towards inclusive and transparent institutions have slowed down the country's development efforts. The IPC acute food insecurity analysis issued for Afghanistan in November 2020 projects that 13.15 million people (42% of the population) will be affected by high levels of food insecurity (IPC levels 3 crisis and above) between November 2020 and March 2021. Furthermore, OCHA predicts that the number of individuals affected by food insecurity may rise to 17 million. Specifically, Samangan province is classified as IPC level 4 emergency, with roughly 215,000 individuals (50% of the local population) affected by hunger and malnourishment. Additionally, the 2019-2020 Afghanistan Winterization evaluation reveals that a lack of humanitarian support results in households adopting negative coping strategies and being placed in more vulnerable and desperate situations. COVID-19 came up to further destabilise the vulnerability of the population. In Hazrat-e-Sultan, the district targeted by this intervention, only 34% of interviewed women of reproductive age were eating five or more food groups and only 29% of the households had food consumption score at the acceptable level. 78% of the households had “poor” food expenditure share and 50% of the households had high rCSI. 15% of the households were headed by children and women where majority of women headed households were widows and 11% of the households were headed by disabled persons. Only 29% of the population has an acceptably food consumption score, and 85% of the population relies on reduced coping mechanisms. In order to address the increased food and nutrition security risks and avoid the most vulnerable households to further resort to negative coping strategies during the winter season, Welthungerhilfe will provide timely lifesaving food assistance to 1,071 households (7,500 individuals) of the most vulnerable families in Hazrat-e-Sultan district in Samangan. In addition to food assistance, beneficiaries will receive nutrition and hygiene awareness sessions. The selected modality for the food assistance is cash. This modality has been prioritised following the market analysis that indicates that markets are accessible, functional and food and non-food items are available. In addition, cash is the preferred disbursement modality for the local population, as they expressed to Welthungerhilfe. Each vulnerable household will receive a total amount of USD 45 per month, for a total of USD 180 covering four months of food assistance. The cash distributions will be organised in two times (each two months) through hawala dealers. Welthungerhilfe has a vast experience in disbursing cash through hawala in the area targeted by the project. The distribution of cash will be conditional to the beneficiaries participating of the nutrition and hygiene promotion sessions. Distributions are organised considering specific needs of the population and gender-age considerations. In addition, Welthungerhilfe has put in place strong protocols to prevent further spread of COVID-19. In order to ensure the accurate identification of the most vulnerable, while engaging communities for the identification of the most vulnerable, Welthungerhilfe will consult the CDC, and at the same time, conduct sound independent verification surveys based on the methodology proposed by WFP. In addition, the setup of the CRM will allow the timely identification of inclusion and exclusion errors. All targeting errors identified are discussed and addressed with the communities and CDC. The success of this project will be measured through a strong MEAL system that includes baseline, endline and PDM, and which will be complemented by market follow ups and a learning workshop.

title.narrative: Emergency Lifesaving Nutrition Services in the low coverage high caseload districts in Badghis Province

description.narrative:
The designed project aims at ensuring delivery of adequate nutrition/health services, including the malnutrition treatment compromised due to the movement restrictions and other stressors. The disruption of nutrition service provision due overburdened health facilities is expected to deteriorate the nutrition status of children, as well as pregnant and lactating women in the pre-defined high-risk districts (Qadis, Jawand and Abkamari in Badghis province). World Vision (WV) Intends to deliver the required nutrition services through the establishment of 3 Mobile Health and Nutrition teams as well as strengthening decentralized nutrition services in 10 Sub-Health Centers (SHC) in these districts. World Vision will also focus on CHWs, Family Health action Groups to learn key Maternal Infant and Young Child Feeding and nutrition (MIYCN) to increase community awareness on key respective practices. In addition, under this project World Vision promote mother MUAC approach to put mothers at the center of malnutrition screening. The mother MUAC strategies acknowledge that mothers are in the best position to detect the earliest signs of malnutrition and leverages the fact that mothers want to participate as fully as possible in promoting the health and nutrition of their children. The mothers will report on MUAC screening once a month. Further the proposed project will work to strengthen the capacity of Family Health Action Groups, female volunteers and CHWs in Infant and Young Child Feeding to promote key IYCF practices and counselling based on the WHO guideline under the COVID-19 circumstances. These groups will be trained to respond the question of key community members and women in childbearing ages in relation on promotion of breastfeeding and be able to respond any questions that may be asked by each member of the community. The project will focus on early action to avoid severe malnutrition so the project will cover the, borderline’ cases of acute malnutrition through prevention-oriented services such as counselling on optimal care practices to mothers of children who are borderline in terms of their Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC). This approach has potential to reduce the risk of rapid deterioration of the nutritional status of children with a MUAC result of 12.5-13.5 cm. This will be done at the MHNTs level by nutrition nurse and at the community level by community nutrition promoters. The adaptation mechanism will be taken into consideration during any capacity building efforts, IYCF promotion session based on the WHO/MOPH and WV Standard Operating Procedure for training, public gatherings, IEC distribution under the COVID-19 circumstances. The project will focus on the provision of lifesaving referral for those cases that require inpatient services and will ensure that a transportation and treatment facility are provided for them. WV attends the EPR meetings on a weekly basis and will update the key actors including DoPH, UNICEF and WHO on the project progress the project report will be shared on a weekly and monthly basis to the key nutrition cluster focal points and DEWS surveillance focal points. In the EPR meetings, various issues are discussed such as places where the new MHNTs should operate and take proper measures to avoid overlap of same interventions.
The project will focus on provision and maintenance of the heaters for each section of the MHNTs activities and in particular on the nutrition spaces and will make sure solid and proper winterization plan in place.
The project will use the community health promoter and nutrition nurses to record all the children with disabilities as well as disabled PLW in a separate registration book and ensure they receive proper medical assessment and receive curative and counseling health and nutrition service. Through GIK WV will distribute the wheel-chair to them and ensure MHNT and SHC are friendly enough for the children and PLWs with disability.
